Video 9 shows   a cell expressing reporters for PIP3 and F-actin turning toward a needle  Materials and methods Strains, cultivation conditions, and reporters In most experiments the axenic strain Ax2 (Kay laboratory strain;  DBS0235521 at http://dictybase.org) of Dictyostelium discoideum  was  used as wild type and all experiments were at 22°C.

Cell outline segmentation and membrane protrusion analysis were  performed using modified QuimP10 software (http://www.warwick   .ac.uk/QuimP) based on the electrostatic contour migration method (Tyson   et al., 2010).

Greg Miller, Ph.D.1, Jillian R. Tate, M.Sc.2, Julian H. Barth, M.D.3, and Graham R. D. Jones, MBBS.4 Department of Pathology1, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA; Pathology Queensland2, Department of Chemical Pathology, Royal  Brisbane and Women’s Hospital, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia; Blood Sciences3, Old Medical School, Leeds Teaching Hospitals Trust, Leeds, UK;  SydPath4, Department of Chemical Pathology, St. Vincent’s Hospital, Darlinghurst, NSW, and University of New South Wales, Kensington, Australia Harmonization of clinical laboratory results means that results are comparable irrespective  of the measurement procedure used and where or when a measurement was made.
Harmonization 188  www.annlabmed.org http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187ing in different countries.
Harmonization http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187 www.annlabmed.org  189health care providers in general.

Harmonization 190  www.annlabmed.org http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187does not specify the number of steps in a traceability chain for a  particular measurement procedure; however, adopting the few - est number of steps necessary can contribute to smaller uncer - tainty in the final result.

Harmonization http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187 www.annlabmed.org  191bility validation is required for any new reference material and  that many existing reference materials are not fit for purpose be - cause they are non-commutable [16].
Harmonization 192  www.annlabmed.org http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187cedures do not measure the same quantity, it may not be possi - ble for results from those procedures to be harmonized.

Harmonization http://dx.doi.org/10.3343/alm.2014.34.3.187 www.annlabmed.org  193different laboratories or obtained over extended time intervals,  which could include a lifetime, are frequently aggregated into a  common EHR to facilitate coherent care for a patient.

All data were analyzed by the tool RelFinder (http://www.leonxie.com/referencegene.php), which integrated the current major computational programs including geNorm42, Normfinder43, BestKeeper44, and the comparative Delta Ct method45.

To help the readers map our results on each specific VSD, the MSA is available for download in the supplemental material, as well as a file with the complete set of parameters of the HMM used in this work The file format of the latter (.hmm) is compatible with the HMMER webserver (http://hmmer.janelia.org/search/hmmsearch) and can be used to generate an MSA using a different (possibly the most up to date) sequence database.

Ankrd1 mice were generated in the University of Arizona (UA) BIO5 GEMMCore from embryonic stem cells obtained from the KOMP consortium (http://www.knockoutmouse.org/); the MARP1  gene (encoding the Ankrd1 protein) was targeted using the  VelociGene technique with the ZEN-UB1 cassette.

Data analysis was conducted using three different packages: Expression Console (Affymetrix) with RMA, BRB-ArrayTools (Biometric Research  Branch, National Cancer Institute) with RMA, and Gene Array  Analyzer (http://gaa.mpi-bn.mpg.de/) with either PLIER or RMA.
